results.title: Shaping the news for the consumer
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: Shows the process of preparing a television news story. Discusses the capabilities and limitations of television news, newspapers and magazines.

results.title: Surfing waves
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the action and properties of waves. Aerial views of the seacoast are used to show diffraction and refraction of parallel wave fronts and laboratory examples further exemplify this point. The action of convergent and divergent lens systems is also demonstrated. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Solar energy
results.brief_description: Investigates the possibility of utilising solar radiation. Shows methods of obtaining heat and electricity from the sun, installations already in operation, production of heat for high temperature and metal research, and the domestic use of solar energy. Gives working Australian examples.

results.title: Selective breeding
results.brief_description:
Investigates the deliberate breeding of particular characteristics into different animals. Discusses the idea that many fashionable characteristics can lead to animals which are not functional. Also looks at the breeding of horses and chickens with breeders outlining some of the methods used to produce or maintain particular characterisitics.
Suitable for upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Human machine
results.brief_description: Looks at the problems which confront people with physical disabilities and the ways modern technology can help them. Shows research and production of artificial limbs, the manner in which people with limited movements can become mobile and learn to communicate. Presented by James Dibble. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Digging up ancestors
results.brief_description: Investigates the discovery of extensive fossil beds at Koonwarra, Victoria. The beds are estimated to be around 120 million years old. Professor Jim Warren, an expert in fossil research, discusses his work at the beds and demonstrates how much information fossils can give us. Suitable for early secondary levels. Narrated by John Gaden.

results.title: Design for living
results.brief_description: Looks at the considerations involved in designing homes for different locations and the problems faced in ensuring their suitability for particular functions. Factors include lightweight but strong construction, soundproofing, air conditioning, lighting and specialised construction procedures. Compromises are made to satisfy particular requirements.

results.title: About three hundred million years ago...
results.creator_credit: Jean Hunt, James Allen and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Shows geologists collecting data to make a geological map and the subsequent laboratory work required to identify the structure and composition of the samples collected. Once the information is compiled, the map can be drawn and ideas about the geological history of the area can be formed. Narrated by Sydney Conabere and photographed by Don Whitehurst. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Ghana: primary products
results.brief_description: Shows how a developing country’s economic livelihood depend on the production and export of a narrow range of raw materials. Practically all of Ghana’s export earnings come from a short list of primary products, headed by cocoa, and timber. Concludes with the important point that the slightest shift in world cocoa or timber prices can send shock waves through the whole economy.

results.title: Ghana: using what's around you
results.brief_description: This film shows how people living in a remote areas make do with a narrow range of foods and raw materials obtained from their immediate surroundings and how the rural technique of skilful improvisation with minimal tools and materials has been transferred to market towns.
